customer_name: Out of Africa Wildlife Park LLC

site_name: OUT OF AFRICA WILDLIFE PARK, L L C

citations.narrative:
Portions of the perimeter fence are now less than 8 feet high due to soil erosion. A point along the western section
measured 7 feet 4 inches in height and a point along the northern section measured 7 feet 6 inches in height. A perimeter
fence of less than 8 feet high may not adequately protect the animals inside the facility or be an efficient secondary
containment system. Perimeter fencing for potentially dangerous animals must be of sufficient height to protect the
animals within the facility from entry of outside animals and unauthorized persons as well as function as a secondary
containment system for the animals in the facility.
Correct by 30 June 2023.

On 13 September 2022, staff discovered that a wildebeest named Keva was found deceased and entangled in fencing in
one of the hoofstock enclosures. Staff had noted incompatibility signs consistent with natural behavior between the
yearling wildebeest and the rest of the herd within a week prior to death. The licensee must ensure compatibility among
animals housed in the same primary enclosure or separate incompatible animals, even when displaying natural or
seasonal behaviors, in order to protect their health.
Corrected by time of inspection 13 March 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
End Section

narrative:
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
Portions of the perimeter fence are now less than 8 feet high due to soil erosion. A point along the western section 
measured 7 feet 4 inches in height and a point along the northern section measured 7 feet 6 inches in height.  A perimeter 
fence of less than 8 feet high may not adequately protect the animals inside the facility or be an efficient secondary 
containment system.  Perimeter fencing for potentially dangerous animals must be of sufficient height to protect the 
animals within the facility from entry of outside animals and unauthorized persons as well as function as a secondary 
containment system for the animals in the facility.  
 
Correct by 30 June 2023. 
3.133  Critical
   
Separation. 
On 13 September 2022, staff discovered that a wildebeest named Keva was found deceased and entangled in fencing in 
one of the hoofstock enclosures.  Staff had noted incompatibility signs consistent with natural behavior between the 
yearling wildebeest and the rest of the herd within a week prior to death.  The licensee must ensure compatibility among 
animals housed in the same primary enclosure or separate incompatible animals, even when displaying natural or

seasonal behaviors, in order to protect their health.   
 
Corrected by time of inspection 13 March 2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative. 
 
End Section
